messageBody:
Jan,

You can use JUnit for longer-running tests, but there are some assumptions
JUnit embodies that will cause some problems. JUnit assumes tests are
atomic--they run or don't run, they run in unit time. Integration tests
often take a long time to run, so interim feedback is valuable. Integration
tests can usefully have multiple failures, where that is less common with
unit tests. OTOH, tests are tests--independent self-checking bits of code
that run and get reported--and for that part of running integration tests
JUnit works fine.

It seems to me to be a tradeoff between the simplicity of running all tests
as JUnit tests and the challenges of getting the integration tests to run as
JUnit tests. Different contexts will requires different solutions. If I had
a few integration tests, I'd make them work with JUnit. If I had a large
suite of integration tests that played a prominent role in development, I
would use some other tool and integrate my unit testing results with the
integration results.

Regards,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

_____

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Jan
Kroeze
Sent: Tuesday, September 02, 2008 1:05 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] JUnit And Larger Scale Tests



Hi all!

I'm a bit of a newb to the whole TDD thing, but I understand that unit tests
are supposed to be blazingly fast and not access the hard drive, network,
database or anything external to the code itself. To this end, I understand
that a framework such as jMock can be used.

So far, so good. But I find JUnit to be extremely useful for writing
integration, system and user acceptance tests as well.

Here's my question: what is the official position of the JUnit community on
using JUnit to do larger scale tests? Is there a better framework, or is it
common practice to use JUnit for these tests as well?

--
Jan Kroeze
